question: Clause... give me a double whiskey with beer chaser. And you won't make a dime sticking your nose in other people's business.
answer: Helmut, darling, are you all right?

question: Do I look like I'm not all right?
answer: I was so worried about you... Your dinner is cold and I couldn't imagine what happened to you...

question: Were you really worried about me or your stupid dinner was getting cold?
answer: Sweetheart, I care about you... I love you... I worry about you... I can't help those feelings...

question: If there is anything I don't need right now... it's your super- sentimentality...
answer: Helmut... what's tormenting your soul? Please let me help you... talk to me... I don't care what it is... I love you... I'm your friend... you can trust me to understand...

question: I can't trust anybody... I don't know how to trust anybody...
answer: I'm not anybody! I'm your wife!

question: I'm sorry, my love... I'm so sorry... You're right! You're not anybody. You're my wife and I love you, too... So very much I just have no one to fight back at... I'm lost and alone, I can't handle the disgrace of failure... the pain of being a has- been is more than I can bear...
answer: Schmidt again? Gustav again? When will you learn they fear you and they know how vulnerable you are now... if they can beat you down then they needn't worry about you coming back to haunt them.

question: They worry about me? Don't be ridiculous... they just took the last comic bit away from me... because of a silly accident... I'm now down at the bottom, just a stooge assisting a not-so-funny clown.
answer: But they can't take your talent away... That's your strongest force!

question: What the hell are you talking about? What talent? And if I had any it's being suffocated into nothing... And that's just what I am now... nothing... No one... just empty... a prop to be used and mis-used... how does my great talent stand up to those odds?
answer: By not quitting... You must fight! Creative survival is even more difficult than human survival... You must fight!!! Go to Schmidt... Force a confrontation... Don't let Gustav win... make Schmidt see what an injustice they are imposing on you... Please, my love, fight! Make your world better by fighting for it... You can do it... I know you can...

question: I will go now and see Schmidt... I will tell him I won't take any more degradation... I will tell him I am a "clown" not a stooge... A "clown"... A special person... A special clown...
answer: Go, my love... Go and fight for what you know is right... I will warm your dinner and wait for you to come home.

question: A funeral is usually in order when someone dies. The trouble with man today is that he takes everything for granted... he thinks things he's told to think... and accepts it! Just because we know meanings of words we use them and we fool ourselves... people should use the dictionary more... look up words like good... bad... honest... loyal... especially loyal, I know what loyal means, and I have always been that... but does anyone care? No! Of course not... Only when it is expedient... When it isn't --- --- ZIPPPP! You're out! And that goes for you too... Mine Fuhrer... ... you, too, are a fool. You allow yourself to think you have "loyal" followers... Ha! Wait until they've had it with you... You'll get yours... all the smiling, bowing, heel clicking idiots will shaft you too. And you will deserve it because if you allow people like Herr Schmidt to got about his business of lying, and cheating, and being disloyal, one day all the Schmidts in Germany will turn on you and you will finish as the dumb little corporal you started as, and never know what hit you... He really has to be stupid -- I could help him by telling him about the people he thinks are good Germans... Ha! What are you staring at? Didn't you ever see a man drink before? What's the matter? Haven't you guys got a sense of humor? You must have! Look how you're dressed! Grown men in their little soldier suits... And the black coats and gloves... Like in a movie... Real cloak and dagger stuff... Didn't you Gestapo guys ever know that everybody can spot you a mile away? Listen, if you really wanted to be unnoticed... You should dress like plain people, then nobody would know you... You might even wear straw hats and shorts... Straw hats and shorts!! That's funny! Now that's really funny, isn't it? Straw hats and shorts! Well, isn't that funny? Think of it... That's funny! Why don't you laugh? I know why you're not laughing... Because things you hear, you have to think about... I'll show you something that you'll laugh at because all you'll have to do is watch... Ve vill conquer the world... Heil me! Heil me! Heil me!
answer: STEINER !!!! Get in here! Do I see what I think I see here? Never put your hands on my desk... is that clear? MOVE IT!! Now tell me, is this brief correct? Is that prisoner, the drunk, the one that impersonated the Fuehrer? I get all the weirdos... Alright, Corporal, send him in! Alright, come in, sit down! Are you Helmut Doork?

question: Doork, yes sir, Helmut Doork! I am he! Yes sir, that is correct, Doork!
answer: And are you a clown in the circus?

question: Not JUST A CLOWN! I am Helmut Doork, Premier Clown! I've clowned for the royal heads of many of our finest countries, why there were times when I had to...
answer: That was years ago... According to these papers you are now just a helper in the circus with little or no importance!!

question: Some things are only temporary... Lt. Reicher! Only yesterday, I had calls from one of the great circus owners in all of Europe... he...
answer: You are NOTHING!! You are a HAS BEEN!! You WERE A CLOWN... You are now a prisoner of the State and that's not funny... Can you make something funny out of that, Clown?

question: No! Lt. Reicher, I can't make anything funny from that thought...
answer: It is no thought... It is fact, Clown, unquestionable fact!! Now down to the issues at hand... Did you willfully and with malice attack the State and impersonate the Fuhrer?

question: I was drunk! It was a mistake! I meant no disrespect... Sir... Honestly, I was drunk and not responsible for my actions and thoughts! And my actions were subconscious!
answer: Subconscious?? Meaning it was all motivated by truth that came out under the influence of alcohol!

question: I am a LOYAL German!
answer: And what kind of commendation would you expect for being a loyal German?

question: I want nothing! But I'm more loyal than most Germans I know...
answer: Like who?

question: Ah, like... re...
answer: Names! Names!!! Who?

question: I don't know...
answer: Sir!!!

question: I don't know, sir...
answer: But you said other Germans... What OTHER Germans... Who are they? Why aren't they loyal? Who?

question: I'm not responsible for what I say now...
answer: Why? You're not drinking... you said you weren't responsible last night because you were drunk! Are you drunk now?

question: No, sir!
answer: Then why are you not responsible now?

question: I don't know!!
answer: SIR!!!

question: I don't know -- sir !!!
answer: Why are you not responsible? Why? Why? Why? Why?

question: Excuse me, sir, but I wonder if you would help me... you see...
answer: No! Go away!

question: You don't understand...
answer: You don't understand... I said go away !!

question: HELMUT !
answer: Move along... you swine... move... we haven't got all day... move... move... one-two-three-four -- Move it... move it... move... move... hurry... faster... faster... Now I would be glad to help you, Fraulein... shall we start with a drink? There is a lovely little bar around the corner...

question: Tsk! tsk! tsk! shame on you, Doork... shame... don't you want to grow big and strong like me? We must eat our food! Do we want Uncle to feed the little man? And now one for Aunt Ada... Let go, Doork, let go... it's the soup that makes us big and strong... not the spoon... LET IT GO! Now let's try it again... I said let's try it again... Oh, I know why you're unhappy... soup without bread is terrible... Isn't that better? Now take some soup...
answer: I've had enough, thank you... No more, please... Please!

question: I'm surprised at you, Doork, you've been here two years now, you should have learned we, of the Third Reich, never acknowledge the weak, sniveling, begging of you swine... that's all you're good for... begging... pleading... praying... you're a disgrace to the human race. That's why we of the superior race must do away with all of you... And we will! We will! Do away with all of you. You're worthless pigs... with no courage, no guts, why if anyone did to me what I just did to Doork I would kill him! Why don't you kill me, Doork? Go on... kill me... kill me... take the knife from the table and kill me...
answer: I would kill you... but I am getting my release any day now... and I won't do anything that would spoil my chances...

question: Your release? Release? They told me you were funny... but I never realized just how funny you are... RELEASE ????
answer: Dear God, please hear me!

question: Dear God, please hear me!
answer: He hears you, my son... Here, here, easy, you can't do this to yourself...

question: You frightened me, Johann, I'm sorry...
answer: You have nothing to be sorry for... Fear isn't something controlled by man... fear can not be conferred with... there isn't anyway known to mankind where man can say to himself... "I will not be afraid"... Oh, certainly man can try to fight it... but faith and believing are man's only chance... You must have faith... you must!

question: I have faith... but not always... sometimes it eludes me... I can't remember to remember it.
answer: But that's natural... you can't expect to be perfect in what you try to do...

question: I don't know...
answer: I heard what happened at breakfast this morning with ROTHMAN, the guard...

question: Will they do something to me? What have you heard?
answer: Nothing, absolutely nothing... don't worry about it... I just wanted you to know that I believe you handled yourself admirably...

question: That was one time I didn't care for the laughs I was getting from some of the men...
answer: Of course you didn't... but I'm sure you know man laughs for two reasons... one because something is funny... two, because they fear showing fear... they laughed because "there but for the grace of God go I!"

question: Do you really think so?
answer: I'm certain of it!

question: Thank you, Johann. I always feel so much better after you talk to me...
answer: I'm glad, Helmut, I'm very glad... you know you can always talk to me, about anything...

question: Oh! I almost forgot... Before breakfast this morning, I spoke to one of the guards, a very intelligent one, and he seems quite nice and friendly too. Well, he said that the Gestapo has set up a special review board to handle cases just like mine. And he said he would get me a form, a special form. Just been printed up. And I'm to fill it out. Isn't that good?
answer: How many times since you've been here, have you filled out forms? Twenty? Thirty times??

question: But this is different. It's entirely new. See? These are made up by the Gestapo itself... and the form will go directly to Berlin, to Gestapo headquarters. That's the important thing about this... the Gestapo's in on it. That's a very good sign. Isn't it a good sign?
answer: Yes, my son, it is a good sign.

question: And I have to be very careful of everything I put down on the form. The tiniest detail could make the difference. Don't you agree?
answer: Isn't it strange? They are free to go anywhere they want, and they come here to nest. Watch the birds eat, Helmut... it's so cute...

question: I'm sure I've got everything here... The important facts from the moment I was arrested, the questions the Gestapo officer asked me... now what was his name again? I can't seem to remember what his name was... What the devil was his name?
answer: HELMUT !

question: Oh, yes, Johann... I'm sorry... you were saying?
answer: You're not a religious man, are you, Helmut?

question: Well, I... ah...
answer: Not sure I am myself anymore. Yet... when I see those birds, I wonder... were they sent here to let us know this place really isn't God forsaken?

question: Hey, Galt! Come over and look at this!
answer: What is it?

question: Ain't it cute?
answer: It's a God damn posie!

question: Looks kinda sick, doesn't it?
answer: It's one of them potato things... and it sure as hell is sick!

question: Maybe we should put it out of its misery.
answer: No, we don't want to do that... we might break someone's heart. Whose little plant is this?

question: No, we don't want to do that... we might break someone's heart. Whose little plant is this?
answer: The plant is MINE!

question: Is it now? Tell me precious... do you knit, too?
answer: If necessary, I can... and I do !

question: You and your posies...
answer: That was close...

question: Where were you when I need you?
answer: I make love, not war! Hey, that's pretty good... I made that up... Make love, not war! I bet that would make a good slogan someday...

question: Come in! What the hell are you doing here? Who gave you permission to leave your quarters? Are you some kind of privileged character? Then what are you doing out of the barracks?
answer: If you'll shut your stupid mouth maybe I can answer one of your questions!

question: I have a STUPID MOUTH?
answer: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to raise my voice...

question: The volume of your voice isn't the issue... it's what comes out of your mouth that disturbs me... maybe you need a little lesson in respect and courtesy... ... and maybe I've been a little too soft with you... You see, Doork, I knew why you came in here... I knew why you left your barracks without permission... It's just that I hadn't heard you mention your release papers for so long I had hoped I could hear you begging once more...
answer: I'm sorry...

question: I was just going to ask him about the forms... my release...
answer: That was not the time, believe me! Hurt much?

question: No, I'm alright... thank you. Johann, why do they pick on me? I've never done anything to them.
answer: You've never done anything for them!

question: You think I should have performed?
answer: The men would have appreciated it.

question: Johann!
answer: What is it?

question: They don't believe me, do they? I mean about being a clown?
answer: Oh, I'd say you've convinced most. However -- There is one you haven't convinced... You, Helmut... you!

question: Here.
answer: How're the shoes?

question: Perfect. Don't forget the bowl.
answer: Hey, Doork! My shoes! I said you could use 'em, not ruin 'em.

question: I had to fix them this way... for the act, you know. Wait till you see how funny it is.
answer: Yeah. But will I feel like laughing when it gets cold!

question: Don't worry.
answer: Worry! I'm the one who'll get frost bitten toes, not you.

question: When I return them, they'll be like new. I promise.
answer: For what you've done to my shoes I should get more food. Remember... you fix them before you bring 'em back.

question: You can laugh. He isn't always after you for something.
answer: No?

question: What's that?
answer: Chalk.

question: What for?
answer: Says he can mash it into a powder and put it on his face.

question: I've been meaning to ask you. Heard anymore about the request for a review of your case?
answer: Did you hear the laughs I got yesterday? Not just from the children... but the adults, too.

question: Never thought of that.
answer: They said I couldn't come up with anything new. At the circus. Schmidt and the rest. Wait'll they see my act now. It's funny. Really funny. Isn't it?

question: The children certainly enjoy it.
answer: What I needed was time. Time to concentrate on new material. A man's got to have time alone.

question: You call this being alone?
answer: Do you think... maybe... they'd let me go to other camps and entertain? I'd have to get to the Commandant. Would need his permission. If you have time later, I'd like you to see something I've been working on. I hunch down and do a tiny soldier parading. Think they'll like it?

question: Who? The adults?
answer: The children, of course.

question: Heil Hitler. Come in. Oh, stand at ease. And, close the door. I don't have to tell you why your Commandant was relieved of his command here. This prison is a disgrace. Disgrace! The latitude allowed by him will not be tolerated by me. Understand? That includes the staff. I'm going to turn this place into a model prison, a credit to the Reich. Understand? Speak up.
answer: Yes, Colonel.

question: This isn't the first prison the SS has had to take over from the military. Military men are too soft to deal with those... Scharff starts to speak but quickly changes his mind.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: You were about to say something?
answer: Oh... I... was just going to say that I didn't hold with the soft treatment of the prisoners.

question: Good! Our first order of business is to prepare... Our first order of business is to prepare all non-Aryan prisoners for shipment in two weeks.
answer: Where are they being sent, Colonel?

question: Work camps.
answer: But we have about 40 children, some only babies, with more scheduled to arrive tomorrow or the next day. They're not going to be much use in a work camp.

question: I'm aware of that. This order covers only the adult prisoners over fifteen. We won't have to wet nurse the children for long. Other plans are being made for... What is that? What is that supposed to be?
answer: That! Well, you see, sir, one of the prisoners used to be a circus clown. Sometimes he gives a little... well... a sort of show -- for the children.

question: A show! Is this a prison camp or a traveling circus! Am I correct in assuming that those children are on the non-Aryan side of the camp?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: And the... buffoon? A German?
answer: Yes, Colonel.

question: Am I to believe you aren't aware of the general order absolutely forbidding fraternization?
answer: I know about it, sir.

question: Close the window. Just what do you think fraternization means, Lieutenant Scharff ?
answer: Communication. Social contact. Giving aid, talking...

question: How long has this been going on?
answer: Just the last two or three weeks.

question: And the Commandant approved?
answer: Well, sir, children are very hard to handle.

question: This clown! Who is he?
answer: It's... I know. It's Doork, the Great.

question: Not his clown name, you idiot. His number. His identification.
answer: If I have the Colonel's permission to leave, I will check it at once.

question: Later. Right now I want these performances halted. Understand?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Immediately!
answer: Yes, sir !

question: That's all. Show's over. Everybody clear out.
answer: What's wrong?

question: Get back to the barrack. You heard me. Show's over. Go on. Get away. Move, damn it, before I come over there and... Get them moving before somebody gets hurt.
answer: That's all the show for today. Go back inside. That's right now, go along. I'll see you tomorrow. Goodbye. Goodbye. Until tomorrow.

question: Get inside and take that stuff off your face.
answer: I don't understand. What's the matter?

question: Orders. No more shows.
answer: You mean... not ever?

question: That's right.
answer: But we weren't doing any harm.

question: The Commandant thinks you are.
answer: The Commandant?

question: The new Commandant. He minds.
answer: Just because I make them laugh a little...

question: You know the rule... no mixing with Jews.
answer: I wasn't mixing! I was only...

question: Because of the laughing.
answer: Why should that bother them?

question: When you rule by fear, laughter is the most frightening sound in the world.
answer: I can't go out there. I can't take another day of them staring at me.

question: They'll get over it. Disappointment is no stranger to those children.
answer: They look at me as though it was all my fault. Haven't they been told why I can't...

question: I'm sure they have.
answer: Then why do they stare?

question: It's amazing how a thing like this can feed off itself. Think how lucky we would be if we could do that.
answer: I sewed a button on. Look all right?

question: Fine.
answer: I did make them laugh. Didn't I? I wish they'd get them out of here. Prison is no place for little children.

question: We've been all over that before. You've got to stop thinking about them.
answer: You're right! I've got to think of myself.

question: It's too hot in here. I'm going to get some air.
answer: Johann... do you think there's any possible way I could talk to the Commandant. Maybe I could make him understand...

question: There's nothing you can do... but forget.
answer: How can I! They were my own very special audience. And now they stare at me as if I had betrayed them.

question: They're children, Helmut. You can't expect them to understand the madness of adults.
answer: If I could talk to them. To the children themselves -- that would help, wouldn't it? If I explain it to them -- then they'll know I am not mad at them.

question: You go near that fence once again... and you're taking your life in your own hands. You know that as well as I do.
answer: I would just need a minute. A minute to talk to them. I wish to God I didn't care. I wish to God I could forget them. But I can't.

question: I'm going to ask you a question, Helmut, and I want you to think carefully before you answer. The reason you can't get them out of your mind -- is it because you need them -- for you audience? I want the truth.
answer: I know I can't perform for them anymore. I know that. I really don't know what the reason is. I think it's got something to do with... well, I don't want those little ones to think I've turned against them, too. That's why I've got to do something. Something.

question: You'll be taking a chance. A great chance. All right! Come on then.
answer: Where are you going?

question: You want to talk to the children? Well, I think I can help you.
answer: There's no reason for you to get involved in this.

question: No, no. I can't. The guards won't let me. Not now. Maybe some other day.
answer: They're bad.

question: What is it? What happened?
answer: He hurt himself.

question: Shhh. Shhh. Don't cry. It's going to be all right. Be careful when you're near this fence. Here, wrap this around it. I'll make it all better. Hush now. Stop crying. Please. Look... Look at this. There, that's better. No more crying now. What's the matter with them?
answer: They're new. We can't understand them. All they do is cry.

question: Yes. Yes. Yes, I understand perfectly. However, I don't see how we can be held responsible. Our orders were very clear. We were to have the freight car ready to be picked up at midnight. Of course, I'm aware the operation must be kept secret. I just don't have the staff to send down there now and... Yes, I'll wait. The freight car wasn't picked up.
answer: It's still down there on the siding!

question: Some stupid mix up. If they think... Yes, General. Yes, I'm as distressed about the situation as you are. Yes. Personally! Immediately! Yes, General. You can leave it in my hands. Heil Hitler! Who did you leave in charge down there?
answer: Sergeant Hoffman. Very reliable.

question: Apparently not reliable enough. The cargo seems to be raising quite a fuss.
answer: Fifty children, sir! In a boxcar!

question: I know. I know. But the siding isn't far from town. The General doesn't want unauthorized persons getting curious. Understand?
answer: I'll get some men down there right away.

question: Men! You'll get yourself down there. And take at least a dozen guards with you. Don't let anyone get close to that boxcar... under any circumstances. No one !
answer: Yes, sir. Sir? I wondered, sir, if you might have any suggestions as... well... how do we quiet children?

question: Use any method you can, but shut them up. That's an order.
answer: Sir, the clown! The one who amused the children

question: Out of the question. The man's being disciplined for that very thing. We can't change our position now.
answer: No one need know.

question: He'd know.
answer: Sir, if I could guarantee he'd never say anything. You see, sir, he's been trying to get a review of his case. Claims he's here by mistake. I could tell him you would recommend the review.

question: A man who wants something. Good. Very good strategy, Lieutenant. However, when you bring him back here, return him to solitary and keep him there. I've seen the best of men, after several years in solitary, unable to remember even their own names.
answer: Then I have your permission to take the clown.

question: Wish you could've gotten the big shoes. The children laugh so when they see them flopping up and down. The Commandant, himself, asked for me! You say he's personally requesting a review of my case! Why, that means I'm practically on my way back to Berlin. Should be red. Mouth looks better in red. Know the first thing I'm going to do when I get to Berlin? Buy an overcoat with a fur collar. Had such a coat. Very elegant. Very elegant. It's a good idea... moving the children. Prison's no place for children. I said all along that it was some kind of mistake.
answer: Finish your makeup. We're almost there.

question: Know what Johann Keltner said?
answer: Who?

question: Keltner. From my barracks. The minister. He said... Let me think. He said... men who wage war on children. That's it. Men who wage war on children... commit such a crime... ... such a heinous crime. That's it. Men who wage war on children commit such a heinous crime that even the devil damns their souls.
answer: Wait here. Any word about the train yet? Anyone been around? With all that wailing, it's a wonder. Couldn't you keep them quiet? Keep a tight guard on the whole area. No one gets near here. Understand? You post them. Leave that here. Over here, Clown.

question: They're crying.
answer: Take that in to them.

question: What is it?
answer: Bread. They won't wait so loud with their mouths full.

question: How... how long have they been here?
answer: You just get in there and keep them quiet. You can do that, can't you? Do a good job and I'll personally ask that you get a favorable decision on your case. Understand?

question: Now, now, there's nothing to cry about. We're going to have fun. Here. I brought you something. The children pounce on the sack and tug at it, unsure what it is except that it's a gift from Helmut. Wait now. Don't open it yet. Wait'll I get in. You help me. Look, I'm a Jack-in-the-box. We're all Jacks-in-the-box -- the same box. Well... who's hungry. All right, I want everybody to sit down. When I count three, everybody sit. Ready? One, two... Oh, you're too fast. Three! Now... what'll we do?
answer: I want to see my Mommy.

question: You would? All right.
answer: You know where she is?

question: She's right here with you.
answer: I don't see her.

question: That's because you don't know how to look. I'll show you. Close your eyes. All of you... close your eyes. Everybody's eyes shut? Now, think about your mommys and Daddys... There, don't you see them? Can't you see their faces? So you see! They're right here with you. All you have to do is look in your hearts.
answer: Does Mommy see me, Doork?

question: Yes, she does. She has you safe in her heart, too. I've got an idea. You all know my name, but I don't know yours. So let's find out everybody's name, shall we? You... come here and I'll show you what we'll do. What's your name?
answer: Willie.

question: Willie. That's a good name. How do you spell it? Fine. I'll just write that on top of your head. There. See, this way we'll all be able to tell everybody else's name just by looking at his head.
answer: Did you really?

question: Of course I did. Here... Tell him what it says.
answer: Really? Truly?

question: Be careful. Don't smear it. Let's see now... Yes. You shall be next. What is your name? Forgive me. I don't speak your language. See! We understand each other. Now... Willie. Doork. Willie. Doork. A beautiful name! Now you tell all the children. It's such a pretty name... say it again. I-N-G-A. There it is. Let's see now. Who wants to be next. You? Her?
answer: So the little children will know her name.

question: Of course. That way she can't get lost, can she? What's her name?
answer: Frederika.

question: Frederika? Frederika! Couldn't we just make it Freda?
answer: Oh, no! Frederika.

question: Clown. Clown, can you play one of these? I got it to send home to my boy... but if it'll help...
answer: It will. It will.

question: You won't say anything to the Lieutenant.
answer: I promise. Guard... guard. It's going to be dark soon. The little ones may be afraid. Do you think... well... could you get some kind of a light for in here?

question: Want to get me in trouble? I would if I could.
answer: I know. I know you would. What's the matter? It's all right -- just a bad dream.

question: We're moving. What's happening? What was the noise? Doork, where are we going?
answer: It's nothing. You're going for a train ride. What do you think of that? A real train ride.

question: Is it far? Are you coming, too? I don't want a train ride.
answer: Oh, it'll be fun. I would like to come, but I don't think I can.

question: Please come, Doork. Please. Please. Please.
answer: I can't. They want me to stay here. But... I'll come to see you. Soon as I can. And, I want you all to promise me to be very good. No crying. If you want me... remember, just close your eyes.

question: What's this now? Crying? After all the fun we've had?
answer: It's his birthday. He thought there would be presents.

question: He's a Czech. Do you speak...
answer: Of course not!

question: Then how do you know it's his... birthday?
answer: He told me.

question: He speaks German?
answer: No.

question: But he told you it's his birthday? What date is this?
answer: Why, it's his birthday! Don't you believe him?

question: Of course, I do. Tell him I wish him a happy birthday.
answer: He knows that. But... but what're you going to do about a present?

question: I'm glad that's over. Call in the sentries.
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Kessler in the car?
answer: Kessler?

question: The clown?
answer: I... I guess he is, sir.

question: You GUESS! I told you to get him off the train.
answer: I told him, sir. HE was standing right by the door. I'm sure he got off.

question: Did you see him?
answer: Why, I...

question: DID you?
answer: You told me to see that the car was coupled on. When I came back... Why wouldn't he get off?

question: Idiot! Guards. GUARDS! The clown prisoner is missing. He may have escaped. Search the area. If he got off the train he must be around here someplace. You know what happens if he gets away.
answer: He can't get very far.

question: I don't know.
answer: Everybody up. No noise. Who the hell are you?

question: Where are we?
answer: How the devil did you get in here?

question: I... I'm from the other prison. Got locked in -- by accident.
answer: Ah, for... Sergeant!

question: How did that happen?
answer: I... I was taking care of the children back there and... accidentally got locked in.

question: Of all the... What's your name?
answer: Doork. Helmut Doork.

question: Do as he says. And, don't worry, I'll be with you soon. I promise.
answer: Come along, now.

question: This is just another prison.
answer: What'd you expect?

question: I thought the children were going to a better place.
answer: Close the door, and wait out there. You're a remarkable man. Very remarkable. Have you any idea where you are? Auschwitz. This is Auschwitz. Mean anything to you? You may have observed we're enlarging our facilities. Still a great deal of work to be done. It's going to be our most efficient, most modern prison. And, I might add, most unique. Yes, you are a remarkable man. I always wonder about remarkable men. Why did you come here?

question: I explained. I got locked in the boxcar and...
answer: Ah, yes. An accident. Unavoidable I suppose.

question: I was taking care -- I mean, the Commandant requested me to take care of the children.
answer: The Commandant! I've spoken to YOUR Commandant. He hs you listed as an escaped prisoner.

question: Escaped! But...
answer: ... it was an accident. Are you one of them, clown?

question: No... no! I'm not one of them. I'm not !
answer: You misunderstand completely. The Judas goat is never killed. He isn't worth killing. I'm just asking you to lead them. Not... even to save your own life? I'm glad to see you're not a self- appointed martyr. Just think! Now you're really one of us.

question: Sir... Sir... could I... could I have a little time with them before ... before...
answer: Yes. Yes, of course. I can give you about half an hour. You see, we're not heartless men here.
